I can't do it anymore.

So it's the executive director and it's ten managers and we're kind of sitting in a circle  and everybody goes around and does like a weekly program update.
Five minutes or so,  maybe ten at the most if there's an issue that kind of needs to be discussed.

And depending on where  you sit is what order you present in basically.
All right.

And I normally, I feel like I do good in my job  but this.
And it builds up more like every day.
The day before is really bad because  I'm prepping for the meeting and so it really starts to consume me then.
I don't sleep the  night before and then by the time I get to the meeting, I'm so anxious and so nervous.
I'm panicking.
You're panicking.
And I just can't.
I just can't.

Yeah.

What's going on then?
By the beginning of the meeting, when I've sat down, I feel like I'm breathing harder.
I'm starting to sweat and I feel like my face is turning red.
My palms are really sweaty.
I'm constantly having to wipe them off on my pants.

My stomach just gets in knots.
I feel nauseous.

But even then when I speak, I stutter and I stammer over my words and I don't say everything  I need to even though I have a cheat sheet essentially and I can read from it.
I still  feel like I'm missing things and I'm leaving things out.
My voice doesn't project so I end  up speaking very softly and like I said, I'm stuttering.

No.

So you're already having anxiety.

Well, if I manage somehow to get there early enough and I can get an early enough  seat like to sit like right next to my boss or like one or two away, then I'm actually pretty  okay because I can kind of get it over and done.

I can  stay.
I've had to go.
So before the presentations come around to you, you get up and leave the room.

I feel like during the presentation, I feel almost like everything,  it's like everything stops and then when it's done and it goes to whoever's next,  it's like, it's almost like a physical sense of relief, like, okay, that's over and everything  starts to relax and calm down, but then I feel miserable.

And I feel so,  so miserable that I feel like I've disappointed him and so I've disappointed me.
